metadata.title: Liver Chemistries in COVID-19 Patients with Survival or Death: A Meta-Analysis Qing-Qing Xing E-mails: Qing-Qing Xing

abstract.text: Word count: 2750 45 Word count of abstract: 237 46 Number of tables: 1; Number of figures: 5 47 Number of supplementary figures: 5 48 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

ABSTRACT 49 Background and Aims: Although abnormal liver chemistries are linked to higher 50 risk of death related to coronavirus disease (COVID-19), liver manifestations may be 51 diverse and even confused. Thus, we performed a meta-analysis of published liver 52 manifestations and described the liver damage in COVID-19 patients with death or 53 survival. 54 Methods: We searched PubMed, Google Scholar, medRxiv, bioRxiv, Cochrane 55 Library, Embase, and three Chinese electronic databases through April 22, 2020. We 56 analyzed pooled data on liver chemistries stratified by the main clinical outcome of 57 COVID-19 using a fixed or random-effects model.
Results: In the meta-analysis of 18 studies, which included a total of 2,862 patients,

body_text.text: 5 Lay Summary 75 Abnormal liver chemistries are linked to higher risk of death related to coronavirus 76 disease (COVID-19). We performed a meta-analysis of 18 studies that included a total 77 of 2,862 patients with COVID-19. We noted that patients died from COVID-19 tend 78 to have different liver chemistries from those are discharged alive and close 79 monitoring of liver chemistries provides early warning against COVID-19 related 80 death.

On the whole, the alteration of liver chemistries between the survival group and non-265 survival group is similar to that between the severe group and the non-severe group, 266 shown in our recent study [10] , although there are some differences. Similar to the age 267 difference between severe and non-severe group, our analysis also found that the 268 average age of the non-survival group was significantly higher than that of survival 269 group. The average ALT and AST in the dead group were also higher than those in 270 the non-survival group. Moreover, both in the non-survival group and survival group, 271 the average AST was higher than ALT, which was also similar to our previous study 272 All rights reserved. 14 [10] . GGT in the non-survival group was higher than that in the survival group. 273 However, there was no statistical significance. This may be due to the under-reported 274 on GGT. TBIL in the non-survival group was also higher than that in the survival 275 group whereas the average values of TBIL in both groups were all within the normal 276 range. ALB in the non-survival group was significantly lower than that in the survival 277 group, which was in accordance with our study between severe and non-severe group 278 [10] . body_text.section: Liver Chemistries in Patients with COVID-19

body_text.text: In this study, we found that the abnormalities of liver chemistries in the non-survival 288 group was worse than that in the survival group, which suggested that we should be Several substantial merits can be seen in this study. First, the literatures focused on 296 COVID-19 related abnormal liver chemistries are rapidly evolving and sometimes 297 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 1, 2020. AKP and GGT tended to be inadvertently ignored, which is even more significant 307 than that in our previous study [10] . We also compared hepatocellular dysfunction 308 between the survival and non-survival cases. The alarmingly high prevalence of 309 hypoalbuminemia and coagulation dysfunction in the non-survival group requires 310 vigilance. Third, we also covered the eligible studies preprinted in medRxiv, which 311 ensured that our meta-analysis has a clear leading position. However, our study has a However, this conversely helps to abate the heterogeneity caused by the physiological 317 differences.

FIGREF0.text: envelope that belongings to the family Coronaviridae. Coronavirus 86 widely distributes in humans and other mammals. In the past twenty years, 87 coronavirus has caused several localized epidemics and even global pandemics, such 88 as severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), Middle East Respiratory Syndrome 89 (MERS), and the ongoing COVID-19. Worldwide, the spread and upward trend of 90 COVID-19 have accelerated dramatically. According to the situation report released 91 by the World Health Organization (WHO), as of April 25, 2020, 2,719,897 92

FIGREF1.text: Emergency of International Concern on January 30, 2020, and further labeled as a 95 pandemic on March 11, 2020. Compared with SARS and MERS, the case fatality rate 96 of COVID-19 is relatively lower, which are 6.8% and 60% in SARS and MERS, 97 respectively [2, 3]. Although the case fatality rate of COVID-19 is lower than those of 98 SARS and MERS, the reproductive numbers of COVID-19 is even higher than of 99 SARS [4]. Due to the huge number of confirmed cases, COVID-19 causes much more 100 deaths than SARS or MERS. 101 Apart from lung injury, COVID-19 also leads to myocardial dysfunction, liver 102 impairment, and acute kidney injury [5, 6]. Chronic hypertension and other 103 cardiovascular comorbidities are frequent risk factors for COVID-19 related death [6, 104 7]. Other conditions can also contribute to death. According to the observation by Wu 105 et al [7], coagulation dysfunction is linked to likelihood of death. Moreover, 106 univariable logistic regression reveals the association between alanine 107 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF2.text: According to the clinical guideline proposed by American College of 113 Gastroenterology, liver chemistries can be classified into three groups, in other words, 114 hepatocellular injury-related indexes, including ALT and aspartate aminotransferase 115 (AST); cholestatic injury-related indexes, comprised of alkaline phosphatase (AKP) 116 and -glutamyltransferase (GGT); and hepatocellular function-related indexes such as 117 albumin (ALB) level and prothrombin time (PT) [11]. In clinical practice, TBIL and 118 direct bilirubin (DBIL), globulin (GLB) levels, and international standardized ratio 119 (INR) are also assessed. Clinical manifestations of COVID-19 are diverse and even 120 confusing. Comprehensive evaluation of the abnormalities of liver chemistries in 121 patients with COVID-19 are rather few. Hence, the aim of this study was to provide a 122 comprehensive view of liver test parameters in the COVID-19 patients with death or

FIGREF3.text: 129 and three Chinese electronic databases (Chinese National Knowledge Infrastructure 130 CQVIP, and Wanfang Data). "COVID-19", "Coronavirus", "SARS-CoV-2", "2019-131 nCoV-2" or novel coronavirus were set as keywords for searching. The PRISMA 132 guideline was implemented in the retrieval of potential studies[12]. Details of 133 searching PubMed were listed in the Supplementary file. Endnote X9.3 (Thompson 134 and Reuters, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania) was employed to manage the retrieved 135 articles. Duplicated articles were removed.

FIGREF4.text: authors (XD and QQX) independently determined the eligibility of the potential 138 studies. Dissonance was arbitrated by the third author (JSP). The inclusion criteria 139 were listed as the following: (1) study population: adult COVID-19 patients with 140 death or survival; (2) study design: case report, case series, retrospective cohort study, 141 prospective cohort study, randomized controlled trial, and case-control study; and (3) 142 language: studies published in English or Chinese. The exclusion criteria were as 143 follows: (1) pregnant women or pediatric patients; (2) patients who lack of nucleic 144 acid data or serology evidence of SARS-CoV2 infection; (3) asymptomatic patients 145 with SARS-CoV2 infection; (3) study design: commentary, editorial, review article, 146 meta-analysis; (4) results: Studies that only reported the percentages of the indexes 147 related to liver chemistries rather than the mean or average values of the 148 corresponding indices, and studies that included only one arm (for example, only data 149 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF5.text: 153 patient age and sex, and liver chemistry-related indexes such as TBIL, DBIL, ALT, 154 AST, GGT, AKP, and ALB levels, were recorded. The main outcome (dead or 155 survival) of COVID-19 was also recorded.

FIGREF6.text: statistical analysis. Continuous variables submitted to normal distribution 159 were expressed as mean ± SD, while median (interquartile range [IQR]) was 160 employed for the expression of those variables conformed to a skewed distribution.

FIGREF7.text: The method developed byLuo et al [13]  was employed to estimate the sample mean162    and SD for the continuous outcomes from the studies that provided summary data of163 median, minimum, and maximum values. Related online tool is provided at 164 http://www.math.hkbu.edu.hk/~tongt/papers/median2mean.html. The 95% confidence 165 interval (CI) was presented in Forest plot. Heterogeneity among studies was detected 166 by the Cochran Q test, with a p value of <0.10 indicating significant heterogeneity. 167 The proportion of total variation among the studies, from which heterogeneity was 168 derived, was measured by the I 2 statistics. I 2 values of <25%, 25-75%, and >75% 169 represent low, moderate, and high heterogeneity, respectively [14]. Funnel plot was 170 used to evaluated publication bias. A subgroup analysis was performed according to 171 the main clinical outcome-death or survival.

FIGREF9.text: the studies included in the meta-analysis 175 Selection process of potential studies was depicted in Figure 1. From the identified 176 1,841 studies, 18 studies were included in the meta-analysis. The characteristics of the 177 enrolled studies are listed in Table 1 [6-8, 15-29]. Information including the study 178 location, sample size, patient age and sex, clinical outcome, TBIL, DBIL, ALT, AST, 179 GGT, AKP, ALB, GLB, PT, and INR was recorded. The mean ages of COVID-19 180 patients discharged alive and died were 56.4 and 68.7 years, respectively 181 (SupplementaryFigure 1). In the enrolled studies, male patients accounted for 55.3%.

FIGREF10.text: Hepatocellular injury-related abnormalities in liver chemistries185    In the enrolled studies, 14 reported assays of ALT or AST in a total of 2,365 patients186 with COVID-19. All of these studies were from China. In the 18 enrolled studies, 14 187 (77.8%) were from Hubei Province, where Wuhan is located. The pooled mean ALT 188 level was 30.9 IU/L in the COVID-19 patients with death and 26.3 IU/L in the 189 COVID-19 patients discharged alive (95% CI: −6.1 to −2.9, p < 0.0001; Figure 2A), 190 with moderate heterogeneity among the studies (I 2 = 42%, p = 0.05). Similarly, the 191 pooled mean AST level was 45.3 IU/L in the COVID-19 patients with death and 30.1 192 IU/L in the patients discharged alive (95% CI: −18.3 to −8.6, p < 0.0001;

FIGREF11.text: ). Potential publication bias existed in ALT/AST was evaluated using a funnel 196 plot (SupplementaryFigure 2). In the patients with COVID-19, the mean AST level 197 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF12.text: Cholestasis-related abnormalities in liver chemistries202    We cannot enroll enough studies to analysis cholestasis-related indexes such as AKP,203 and DBIL levels, since rather few studies focused on these indexes. Of the enrolled 204 studies for the meta-analysis, 3 reported GGT assays and 11 studies reported TBIL 205 measurements. The pooled mean GGT level was 46.3 IU/L in the group with death 206 and 34.3 IU/L in the group discharged alive (Figure 4A). The pooled mean TBIL level 207

FIGREF13.text: However, the mean TBIL levels remained within the normal range in both groups 209 (Figure 4B). For the TBIL levels, moderate heterogeneity was observed among the 210 studies (I 2 = 36%, p = 0.11). Funnel plot for the TBIL levels was shown in 211 Supplementary Figure 4. 212 Hepatocellular function-related abnormalities in liver 213 chemistries 214 Eleven studies compared the mean ALB levels according to the main clinical outcome 215 of COVID-19, between 683 and 1,383 died and discharged alive cases, respectively 216 (

FIGREF14.text: 219 indexes such as PT and INR between the two groups. The patients in the group with 220 dead had longer PT or higher INR (Figure 5B, 5C). Evaluation of publication bias 221 related to ALB level and PT was shown in Supplementary Figure 5.

FIGREF16.text: injury, cholestasis, and hepatocellular dysfunction, can develop in 226 proportion of patients with COVID-19, especially in the patients who eventually died. 227 Briefly, the patients who died of COVID-19 tended to have higher baseline ALT/AST, 228 TBIL, INR, and prolonged PT while lower ALB than the survival cases. The patients 229 with COVID-19 usually had higher AST levels than ALT levels, especially in the 230 non-survival. There was a tendency of the dead cases to arise in the elderly. 231 Should be noted, the pooled percentage of death cases accounted up 31.6%, which 232 was calculated according to the proportion of death cases in each enrolled selected 233 study. It does not intend to mean that the percentage of death cases in the whole 234 population reaches that high. Several reasons that may lead to the higher percentages 235 of death cases in the enrolled study than those in the whole population. First, since the 236 patients in the enrolled studies are all hospitalized or even critically ill patients, it 237 sounds reasonable that the percentage of death case is higher than that in the whole 238 population. Second, the composition difference exists in the enrolled studies caused 239 by the selection of the reporter. Similar to our previous study, most studies focus on 240ALT/AST rather than cholestasis-related indexes such as AKP and GGT levels[10].241In other words, the actual prevalence of abnormal liver chemistries could be 242 underestimated in the studies reporting clinical features of COVID-19. Thus, the role 243 of liver chemistries was compromised in disease monitoring and early warning 244 against potential death cases.

FIGREF18.text: , the following events can also lead to liver injury: sudden cessation 250 of ongoing antiviral treatment in the patients with chronic hepatitis B patients, which 251 may result in sharp deterioration of liver chemistries or acute-on-chronic liver failure; 252 application of high dose corticosteroids without antiviral therapy, which may bring 253 about activate replication of HBV. Clinically, secondary liver injury is far more 254 frequent than direct liver injury [31]. 255 The most frequent complications of deceased patients caused by COVID-19 are the 256 following: acute respiratory distress syndrome, sepsis, acute cardiac injury, type I 257 respiratory failure, followed by heart failure [6]. The percentage of developing acute 258 liver injury is 9% in deceased patients whereas is only 2% in recovered patients [6]. 259 Investigation by Deng et al [17] also indicated the high frequency of developing acute 260 respiratory distress syndrome (89.9%), acute cardiac injury (59.6%), acute kidney 261 injury (18.3%) in the patients with death. Sepsis or liver ischemia caused by acute 262 respiratory distress syndrome or heart failure can further bring about abnormalities of 263 liver chemistries or even disordered coagulopathy.

FIGREF20.text: 280previously observed between the severe group and non-severe group. This suggests 281 that the coagulation function of non-survival group is significantly worse than that of282 survival group. Since almost all of coagulation factors are synthesized in the liver, it 283 can be speculative that the hepatocellular disfunction in the non-survival group was 284 exacerbated under the influence of multiple factors such as hypoxemia, inflammation 285 storm, infection. In fact, severe sepsis is almost invariably associated with systemic 286 activation of coagulation [32, 33].

FIGREF21.text: 289 alert to the risk of death for the patients with significantly abnormal liver chemistries 290 on admission. Dramatical hypoalbuminemia usually developed in the non-survival 291 group. Thus, solid nutrition support is necessary. In addition, if there is obvious 292 coagulation dysfunction on admission, we should be aware of the risk of severe case 293 or even death. It is necessary to correct the coagulation disfunction as early as 294 possible to prevent the further deterioration of the condition.

FIGREF23.text: the patients with COVID-19. Our analysis revealed that abnormal liver 301 chemistries were associated with a worse clinical outcome and even death, which 302 highlights the importance of a more extensive monitoring on liver chemistries for the 303 purposes of both diagnosis and prognosis. Second, three patterns of liver impairment, 304 namely hepatocellular injury, cholestasis, and hepatocellular dysfunction were all 305 extensively covered in this analysis. However, cholestasis-related indices such as 306

FIGREF24.text: 312 few limitations. As mentioned earlier, cholestasis-related indices were remarkably 313 under-reported, which hindered us from getting more precise pooled data. Second, all 314 the enrolled studies came from mainland China, which restricted a more precise 315 estimation of abnormal liver chemistries in the context of diverse other ethnics.

FIGREF26.text: according to the main clinical outcome of COVID-19. Patients with 323 abnormal liver chemistries are at higher risk of worse outcome. Close monitoring on 324 liver chemistries, especially coagulation-related indexes, is beneficial to early warning
